titlestmt.titleproper: Bartram, Edwin Bunting. Papers of Edwin Bunting Bartram, 1925-1963: A Guide

change.item: far00003 converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.xsl (sy2006-06-08).

titlepage.titleproper: Bartram, Edwin Bunting. Papers of Edwin Bunting Bartram, 1925-1963: A Guide
titlepage.author: Archives, Farlow Reference Library of Cryptogamic Botany, Harvard University Herbaria
titlepage.p: © 1998 The President and Fellows of Harvard College

acqinfo.p: The collection was given to the Farlow Herbarium begining in August 1964 by Bartram himself.

bioghist.head: Biography:
bioghist.p: Edwin Buntin Bartram was born on July 28, 1878 in Philadelphia, PA. He dropped out of high school to support his mother and began working at the Insulated Wire Co. of Philadelphia as an office boy. He rose to the position of company manager before retiring at the age of 39.

Bartram was an outdoorsman. He loved fishing, tennis, gardening, botany, and especially bryology. He made many botanical trips with Merritt Lyndon Fernald and between 1909 and 1922 he published numerous papers on the flowering plants of Massachusetts,New Jersey, Pennsylvania, and Arizona. His first publication on bryology appeared in 1922 and never turned back. He was a member of the Academy of Natural Science,Philadelphia Botanical Club,Torrey Botanical Club, New England Botanical Club, and the Sullivant Moss Society. In total Bartram contributed 143 works to bryology, including a number of books. He described many dozens of new species, and was a kind and patient tutor to the young bryologists that sought him out.

Unfortunately in the 1950's Bartram's eyesight began to fail. He began to severely limit his research to a few hours a day. In 1964 he was forced to give up on his work all together because his eyes were almost useless. On December 2, 1964 Edwin Bunting Bartram, a botanist for 55 years and a renowned bryologist for 42, died at his home in Bushkill, Pennsylvania.
Barnhart, J. Botanical Notes Upon Botanists. v.1: 132. Crum, H. "A Tribute to Edwin Bunting Bartram" Bryologist 69: 125-134 (1966)

scopecontent.head: Scope Content:
scopecontent.p: Collection consist of correspondence, specimen lists, keys, and manuscripts. They deal with Bartram's bryological research both in the United States and overseas.

arrangement.head: Series Description:
arrangement.p: The collection is broken down into five series.

Series I - Correspondence. The correspondence dates from 1920- 1964. There are 30 boxes of correspondence. These are arranged by date, and then alphabetically within a specific date range. There are also 10 folders of miscellaneous correspondence to Bartram. These are arranged alphabetically by author and range from 1939-1967.

Series II - Specimen Lists. These are lists of mosses from various expeditions and trips. They are arranged alphabetically by location. Included are Ecuador,Samoa, New Guinea, Venezuela,Polynesia,Chile, and New Zealand. If notes or correspondence accompanied the list it will be noted in the finding aid and filed in behind the specimen list.
Series III - Keys. These are plant keys to different types of moss in different areas that Bartram traveled to. Included are New Guinea and Fiji.
